questionList.questionText: A 1-day-old girl undergoes routine congenital heart disease screening in the newborn nursery.  The patient was born via spontaneous vaginal delivery to a 23-year-old primigravid woman after an induction of labor at 40 weeks gestation.  The pregnancy and the delivery were uncomplicated, and the patient has stayed with her mother since delivery.  The patient is breastfeeding and has voided and stooled twice.  Pulse oximetry obtained while breathing room air is 99% oxygen saturation in the right hand and 91% in the right foot.  The patient is well appearing.  No cyanosis is seen.  Femoral and brachial pulses are 2+.  Which of the following is most likely cause of this patient's clinical presentation?
questionList.explanationText:
Persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn

Pathogenesis

  • Abnormal persistence of elevated fetal pulmonary vascular resistance
  • Right-to-left shunting across ductus arteriosus

Risk factors

  • Lung hypoplasia (eg, congenital diaphragmatic hernia)
  • Meconium aspiration syndrome
  • Infection (eg, neonatal pneumonia)

Examination

  • ↓ Postductal relative to preductal oxygen saturation
  • Respiratory distress & cyanosis
  • Prominent S2

Treatment

  • Oxygenation & ventilation
  • Inhaled nitric oxide (pulmonary vasodilator)

This patient's low postductal (right foot) saturation relative to her preductal (right hand) saturation is consistent with a right-to-left shunt across a patent ductus arteriosus.  Because this patient has strong distal pulses, the most likely diagnosis is persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN).

At birth, physiologically elevated pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) normally decreases with oxygenation and ventilation of the lungs.  In PPHN, also known as persistent fetal circulation, the PVR remains elevated.  Deoxygenated (blue) blood crosses from the pulmonary artery into the aorta and mixes with oxygenated (red) blood pumped from the left ventricle, resulting in a relatively lower postductal saturation.

Risk factors for PPHN include conditions associated with lung hypoplasia (eg, congenital diaphragmatic hernia, Potter sequence), infection (eg, pneumonia), or meconium aspiration.  However, some patients have no identifiable cause and simply have a slower decline in PVR, resulting in mild right-to-left shunts that can persist into the first few days of life, as is likely in this neonate.  Respiratory distress and cyanosis are common, but some infants are asymptomatic.

(Choice A)  Right-to-left shunting across the ductus arteriosus also occurs in conditions in which left ventricular output is obstructed such as coarctation of the aorta.  However, these infants have diminished femoral pulses and often lower extremity pallor due to decreased distal blood flow.  This patient has normal femoral pulses, making hypoplasia of the aortic arch unlikely.

(Choice B)  Left-to-right intracardiac shunts (eg, atrial septal defect, ventricular septal defect) cause oxygenated blood to return to the right-sided circulation before being pumped to the lungs again.  Unlike in this patient, pre- and postductal saturations would be equal and normal.

(Choices C and E)  Total anomalous pulmonary venous return causes oxygenated blood to return to the right side of the heart; affected infants have a right-to-left intracardiac shunt to provide systemic blood flow.  Similarly, conditions with right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (eg, tricuspid atresia, tetralogy of Fallot) require right-to-left intracardiac shunting through a septal defect.  These infants are often cyanotic and do not have a gradient between pre- and postductal saturations because all mixing is intracardiac, occurring before the ductus arteriosus.

Educational objective:
Persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn is characterized by abnormal persistence of elevated pulmonary vascular resistance, causing right-to-left shunting across a patent ductus arteriosus.  Patients have a low postductal saturation compared to the preductal saturation and normal distal pulses.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Persistent pulmonary hypertension

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn
Persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn.

questionList.questionText: An 18-hour-old infant is brought to the newborn nursery for assessment of a murmur.  The patient was born full term via vaginal delivery.  His mother's prenatal course was uncomplicated.  Apgar scores were 7 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes of life, respectively.  The patient has breastfed 5 times for 5 minutes each.  He has had 1 thick, dark, sticky stool and 1 wet diaper.  On examination, the patient has a 4/6 holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border.  He has 2+ brachial and femoral pulses with no brachiofemoral delay.  The liver edge is palpable 1 cm below the right costal margin.  Echocardiography reveals a small (2-mm) defect in the muscular component of the intraventricular septum with a left-to-right shunt.  Which of the following is the most likely outcome of this patient's condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Ventricular septal defect

Small

Moderate to large

Clinical
features

  • Asymptomatic
  • Loud, harsh, holosystolic murmur at LLSB
  • Respiratory distress, poor feeding, poor growth (due to pulmonary overcirculation & high-output LV failure)
  • ± Holosystolic murmur at LLSB; loud S2

Chest x-ray

  • Normal
  • Cardiomegaly
  • Increased pulmonary markings

Management

  • Serial echocardiography
  • Most spontaneously close at age <2
  • Diuretics
  • Surgical closure

LLSB = lower left sternal border; LV = left ventricular.

This patient has an isolated ventricular septal defect (VSD), which is most commonly a membranous or muscular wall defect that creates an abnormal communication between the right and the left ventricles.  At birth, a VSD becomes a left-to-right intracardiac shunt due to rising systemic vascular resistance (↑ left-sided pressures) and declining pulmonary vascular resistance (↓ right-sided pressures).  The symptoms and outcomes of VSD depend on the size of the defect, which determines the amount of excess blood flow shunted to the right ventricle.

Small VSDs deliver only a small volume of blood to the right ventricle and are therefore typically hemodynamically insignificant, as is likely the case in this patient.  Examination classically reveals a holosystolic murmur at the lower left sternal border, and a loud murmur is often suggestive of a small defect due to increased turbulence of flow compared to a large, unrestricted defect.  Most small VSDs close spontaneously by age 2 due to the growth of surrounding tissue.

In contrast, moderate to large VSDs lead to right ventricular volume overload with pulmonary overcirculation and increased venous return to the left side of the heart with left ventricular volume overload.  Symptoms of heart failure (eg, poor feeding, failure to thrive, respiratory distress) usually develop in the first few weeks or months of life.  These defects do not typically close spontaneously, and patients often require diuretics and surgical closure (Choices B and D).

(Choice A)  Unrepaired moderate to large VSDs lead to chronic pulmonary overcirculation, resulting in pulmonary vascular remodeling and pulmonary hypertension.  This complication does not occur in small VSDs due to the small volume of excess pulmonary blood flow.

(Choice C)  Although the risk of subacute bacterial endocarditis (SBE) is slightly increased in patients with VSD, SBE prophylaxis is not recommended for an isolated VSD due to the lack of proven benefit and potential risks of antibiotics (eg, resistance, adverse reaction).  Conditions that require SBE prophylaxis include unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease and a recently or partially repaired (ie, residual shunt) defect.

Educational objective:
Left-to-right shunting through a ventricular septal defect creates a holosystolic murmur best heard at the lower left sternal border.  Small defects, which are typically hemodynamically insignificant due to the small volume of shunted blood, do not usually require treatment because most close spontaneously in early childhood.

questionList.title: Ventricular septal defect

answerChoiceList.choice: Need for subacute bacterial endocarditis prophylaxis

questionList.questionText: A 32-year-old man comes to the office for a routine preemployment physical.  He has been feeling well.  Ten years ago, his father died suddenly at age 54.  Blood pressure is 175/103 mm Hg in the right arm and 180/105 mm Hg in the left, and pulse is 82/min.  BMI is 22.1 kg/m2.  The lungs are clear bilaterally and heart sounds are normal.  Bilateral, nontender, upper abdominal masses are palpated on examination.  Hemoglobin level is 15.2 g/dL and creatinine concentration is 0.8 mg/dL.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluating this patient's condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease

Clinical
presentation

  • Most patients asymptomatic until age 30-40
  • Flank pain, hematuria
  • Hypertension
  • Palpable abdominal masses (usually bilateral)
  • Chronic kidney disease (CKD)

Extrarenal
features

  • Cerebral aneurysms
  • Hepatic & pancreatic cysts
  • Mitral valve prolapse, aortic regurgitation
  • Colonic diverticulosis
  • Ventral & inguinal hernias

Diagnosis

  • Ultrasonography showing multiple renal cysts

Management

  • Aggressive control of risk factors for CV & CKD
  • ACE inhibitors preferred for hypertension
  • Hemodialysis, renal transplant for ESRD

CV = cardiovascular; ESRD = end-stage renal disease.

This patient with early-onset hypertension and bilateral upper abdominal masses likely has autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD), which is the most common genetic cause of chronic kidney disease.  Mutation of the PKD1 or PKD2 gene disrupts the function of polycystin proteins and leads to cystic degeneration of the renal parenchyma that begins early in life.

Most patients are asymptomatic until age 30-40, when cysts have become large and numerous.  Hypertension is a common early disease manifestation and is typically present before any significant decline in renal function.  Other early disease findings can include hematuria, nephrolithiasis, flank pain, and urinary tract infections.  Some patients have an elevated hemoglobin concentration due to increased erythropoietin production (possibly from local ischemia around the renal cysts).  As cystic degeneration progresses with age, patients experience progressive renal dysfunction that eventually leads to end-stage renal disease.

Extrarenal complications of ADPKD include cerebral aneurysms, hepatic or pancreatic cysts, cardiac valvular abnormalities (ie, mitral valve prolapse, aortic regurgitation), colonic diverticula, and ventral or inguinal hernias.  The sudden death of this patient's father suggests rupture of a cerebral aneurysm in the setting of ADPKD.  The diagnosis of ADPKD is based mainly on abdominal ultrasound or CT showing enlarged kidneys with numerous cysts.

(Choice A)  Elevated 24-hour urine cortisol excretion is seen in Cushing syndrome.  Although Cushing syndrome can cause secondary hypertension, it is unlikely in this patient who is not overweight and is feeling well, without suggestive symptoms (eg, fatigue, irritability).  Cushing syndrome may be due to adrenal tumors but is unlikely to cause palpable abdominal masses.

(Choice C)  Captopril-enhanced radionuclide renal scan is used occasionally to diagnose suspected renovascular disease or renal artery stenosis as a cause of refractory hypertension.  However, these conditions are not associated with palpable renal enlargement.

(Choice D)  A high plasma aldosterone/renin ratio is seen in patients with primary aldosteronism (Conn syndrome), which is a common cause of secondary hypertension.  However, it usually involves a unilateral adrenal adenoma that is not easily palpable; bilateral palpable adenomas would be highly unusual.

(Choice E)  Urinary excretion of metanephrines is increased in patients with pheochromocytoma.  These patients usually have a paroxysmal elevation in blood pressure accompanied by headaches, palpitations, and/or diaphoresis.

Educational objective:
Most patients with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease are asymptomatic until age 30-40, when renal cysts become large and numerous.  Bilateral upper abdominal masses are typically palpable on physical examination, and hypertension is an early disease manifestation that typically precedes a progressive decline in renal function.

questionList.title: Polycystic kidney disease

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Polycystic kidney disease and other renal cysts

questionList.questionText: A 60-year-old woman comes to the office due to progressive shortness of breath and chest "tightness" over the last 3 months.  The patient has no known medical conditions and takes no medications.  She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or recreational drugs.  Family history is insignificant.  Blood pressure is 155/92 mm Hg and pulse is 96/min and regular.  Pulse oximetry is 93% on room air.  BMI is 31 kg/m2.  The jugular veins are distended.  A 2/6 systolic murmur is heard at the lower sternal border and increases with inspiration.  Lung auscultation demonstrates scattered wheezes and bibasilar crackles.  There is 2+ symmetric peripheral edema.  Echocardiography shows a globally hypokinetic left ventricle with an ejection fraction of 30% and a moderately dilated right ventricle.  Pulmonary artery systolic pressure is estimated at 55 mm Hg (normal: <35).  Which of the following is the best initial treatment for this patient's cardiopulmonary condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Management of pulmonary hypertension

Group 1
PAH

  • Evaluate for autoimmune CTD, toxins (eg, amphetamines), HIV, schistosomiasis, etc.
  • Pulmonary vasodilator therapy, treat underlying (eg, autoimmune) cause

Group 2
Left-sided
heart disease

  • Echocardiography (± RHC if diagnosis unclear)
  • Optimize left ventricular function (eg, heart failure therapy), treat significant valve disease

Group 3
Lung disease &/or
chronic hypoxemia

  • Pulmonary function tests, chest imaging, polysomnography
  • Treat underlying respiratory condition (eg, obstructive sleep apnea)

Group 4
CTEPH

  • V/Q scan, pulmonary angiography
  • Pulmonary thromboendarterectomy surgery (curative), anticoagulation

General
measures

  • Refer to accredited PH center
  • Maintain normoxia, euvolemia & sinus rhythm
  • Contraceptive counseling, immunization, cardiac rehabilitation
  • Refractory PH: bilateral lung transplant

CTD = connective tissue disease (eg, scleroderma); CTEPH = chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension; PAH = pulmonary arterial hypertension; PH = pulmonary hypertension; RHC = right-sided heart catheterization; V/Q = ventilation-perfusion.

This patient's progressive shortness of breath, tricuspid regurgitation (systolic murmur at the lower sternal border that increases with inspiration), right ventricular dilatation, and elevated pulmonary arterial pressure is consistent with pulmonary hypertension (PH); given the evidence of left ventricular (LV) dysfunction (eg, hypokinesis, ejection fraction 30%) and consequent volume overload (eg, crackles), these findings are suggestive of pulmonary hypertension (PH) secondary to left-sided heart failure.

After identification of PH, the next step is to classify the group because WHO's PH group designation determines treatment:

  • PH due to left-sided heart disease (group 2) is treated by optimizing left-sided heart function.  This patient with newly recognized heart failure with reduced ejection fraction should be treated with initial guideline-directed combination drug therapy (eg, renin-angiotensin system inhibitor, beta blocker, diuretic).  After treatment, associated PH resolves in most patients.  Pulmonary vasodilators are generally avoided due to the risk for acute pulmonary edema (by suddenly increasing pulmonary return in the dysfunctional LV).

  • Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) (group 1) is caused by damage/dysfunction of the pulmonary arteries induced by autoimmune connective tissue disease (eg, scleroderma), drugs/toxins (eg, amphetamines), and other causes (eg, schistosomiasis).  Because of direct artery involvement, PAH responds to the administration of pulmonary vasodilators, in addition to treatment of underlying conditions (Choice F).

  • PH due to lung disease/hypoxemia (group 3) is treated by optimizing the underlying pulmonary pathology, such as bronchodilators for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (Choice D), and maintaining normoxia.  The patient's wheezing is likely a manifestation of LV failure causing pulmonary fluid congestion ("cardiac asthma").

  • Chronic thromboembolic PH (group 4) is treated by surgical stripping of the thrombosed vessel lining (ie, pulmonary thromboendarterectomy).  Typically, lifelong anticoagulation is also administered because an underlying hypercoagulable state is presumed (Choice E).

(Choice B)  Hypoxemia should be avoided in patients with PH because it further stimulates pulmonary vasoconstriction.  Oxygen is generally administered to keep SpO2 >92% and is not a substitute for treating the underlying cause of PH.

(Choice C)  Graded exercise training (eg, cardiac or pulmonary rehabilitation) improves long-term outcomes in  patients with PH and heart failure.  However, this patient first needs appropriate treatment and stabilization of her underlying LV dysfunction.

(Choice G)  Tricuspid regurgitation is extremely common in patients with PH and is a functional consequence of right ventricular enlargement and annular dilation.  PH treatment significantly improves the functional tricuspid regurgitation.  Surgical correction is needed only rarely (eg, if the regurgitant jet severely undermines forward stroke volume).

Educational objective:
Left ventricular dysfunction is a common cause of pulmonary hypertension.  Initial management involves combination drug therapy for left heart failure.

questionList.title: Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension

answerChoiceList.choice: Combination drug regimen for left heart failure

questionList.questionText: A newborn boy is undergoing routine examination in the delivery room immediately following birth.  He was born via spontaneous vaginal delivery at 39 weeks gestation to a primigravid 15-year-old girl.  Delivery was complicated by meconium-stained amniotic fluid.  The mother received prenatal care and had an uncomplicated pregnancy.  At 5 minutes of life, the patient's heart rate is 120/min and respiratory rate is 50/min.  He is flexing his extremities, and he moves and cries vigorously in response to stimulation.  The patient has cyanosis of the hands, feet, and circumoral area; mucous membranes and other skin are pink.  Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient's cyanosis?
questionList.explanationText:
Cyanosis in children

Central

Peripheral

Mechanism

  • ↓ Systemic O2 saturation
  • ↑ Tissue oxygen extraction

Typical causes

  • Pulmonary disease
  • Cyanotic heart disease
  • Vasomotor instability*
  • Cold exposure*
  • Low cardiac output
  • Venous obstruction

Features

  • Diffuse &/or mucosal cyanosis
  • Warm extremities
  • May improve with oxygen**
  • Finger, toe, perioral cyanosis
  • Cool extremities
  • Does not improve with oxygen

*Benign etiologies of peripheral cyanosis.

**Supplemental oxygen may improve central cyanosis due to pulmonary etiologies but will not improve central cyanosis due to right-to-left shunting (ie, cyanotic heart disease).

This newborn has cyanosis, or a bluish discoloration of the skin.  Whereas central cyanosis (ie, diffuse or mucosal involvement) indicates a potentially life-threatening condition, this patient has acrocyanosis, a benign form of peripheral cyanosis.

Acrocyanosis is common in the first few days of life and is characterized by cyanosis limited to the hands, feet, and circumoral area (around the mouth but not involving the lips or mucosa), as seen in this patient.  It is due to vasomotor instability, which leads to slowing of capillary blood flow and increased oxygen extraction in peripheral tissues.  In contrast to inadequate oxygenation seen in central cyanosis, systemic oxygen saturation is normal in peripheral cyanosis.

Management of acrocyanosis in a healthy newborn (like this vigorous patient with age-appropriate vital signs) is parental reassurance and routine care, including universal screening for critical congenital heart disease (CHD).  Screening after 24 hours of life may identify a critical CHD (eg, severe aortic coarctation) that can be asymptomatic initially due to blood flow through the open ductus arteriosus but detected by a difference in pre- and postductal pulse oximetry readings as the ductus constricts.

(Choices A, B, and C)  Chest x-ray, ECG, and echocardiogram are indicated in patients with suspected CHD, including those with central cyanosis or a positive CHD screen, not isolated peripheral cyanosis.  Chest x-ray is also indicated for newborns with respiratory distress (eg, tachypnea, retractions), as seen in meconium aspiration syndrome.  However, newborns who are vigorous with a normal respiratory rate and respiratory effort, as in this case, warrant routine care alone (ie, no imaging) despite the presence of meconium-stained amniotic fluid.

(Choice D)  The hyperoxia test is an assessment of response to 100% oxygen administration.  It can distinguish central cyanosis due to pulmonary disease (improves with oxygen) from CHD (does not improve with oxygen).  The hyperoxia test is not helpful or indicated for peripheral cyanosis, in which systemic oxygen saturation is normal.

Educational objective:
Acrocyanosis is a benign form of peripheral cyanosis that is common in newborns and limited to the hands, feet, and circumoral (but not mucosal) area.  Management is parental reassurance and routine care, including universal screening for congenital heart disease.

questionList.title: Neonatal evaluation

questionList.questionText: A newborn is evaluated for bluish discoloration an hour after delivery.  The patient was born at 37 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery without complications.  Apgar scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively.  Birth weight was 3.4 kg (7 lb 8 oz).  Temperature is 37.1 C (98.8 F), blood pressure is 72/34 mm Hg, pulse is 150/min, and respirations are 40/min.  Pulse oximetry indicates an oxygen saturation of 76% on room air.  On physical examination, the patient is well appearing with no respiratory distress.  Cyanosis is present over the lips, trunk, and extremities.  The lungs are clear to auscultation.  No murmurs are heard on cardiac auscultation.  Muscle tone is normal.  When 100% oxygen is administered, the patient's pulse oximetry reading remains at 76%.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
This newborn has central cyanosis, a blue discoloration involving mucous membranes and/or any part of the skin (but not confined only to the distal extremities [ie, peripheral cyanosis]).  Central cyanosis is caused by excessive deoxygenated hemoglobin, and initial management includes 100% oxygen administration to attempt to improve oxygen saturation and help identify the underlying cause.

In primary pulmonary disorders (eg, meconium aspiration, focal pneumonia), the administration of 100% oxygen typically results in substantially increased (ie, ≥10%) oxygen saturation and improved cyanosis (Choice A).  These patients typically also have respiratory distress or abnormal pulmonary findings (eg, crackles).  In contrast, in cyanotic congenital heart disease such as transposition of the great arteries and tetralogy of Fallot, oxygen administration does not significantly increase oxygenation because of anatomic right-to-left shunting.

Therefore, the most likely diagnosis in this patient is transposition of the great arteries, in which the aorta arises from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle.  Oxygen administration fails to improve hypoxemia because of the parallel circuitry; the oxygenated blood that is delivered to the left side of the heart is pumped back to the pulmonary circulation rather than to the aorta and systemic circulation.  A mixing shunt (eg, ventricular septal defect, patent ductus arteriosus) is needed to supply oxygenated blood to the systemic circulation and allow for infant viability, but flow through the shunt is typically insufficient to cause a murmur.

(Choice B)  Persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn is characterized by elevated pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR), leading to right-to-left shunting through the ductus arteriosus.  Differential cyanosis (ie, preductal > postductal saturation) and respiratory distress (eg, grunting, retractions) are typical.  In addition, because oxygen is a pulmonary vasodilator, administration of 100% oxygen decreases PVR, which would reduce right-to-left shunting and somewhat improve oxygen saturation.

(Choice C)  Polycythemia is most commonly seen in infants of mothers with diabetes mellitus.  It can lead to cyanosis due to excess available hemoglobin and a relatively increased amount of deoxygenated hemoglobin compared to unaffected neonates; however, oxygen saturation would be normal.

(Choice E)  A vascular ring can cause hypoxemia and cyanosis due to external obstruction of the trachea.  Although administration of supplemental oxygen would not improve oxygen saturation, affected neonates would have severe respiratory distress and stridor.

Educational objective:
In neonates with hypoxemia and cyanosis, oxygen administration typically improves oxygenation in primary pulmonary disorders.  In contrast, minimal improvement is seen in cyanotic congenital heart disease (eg, transposition of the great arteries) because hypoxemia is due to right-to-left shunting.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Transposition of the great vessels

answerChoiceList.choice: Persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn

questionList.questionText: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the office for a routine physical examination.  She and her parents have no concerns.  The girl is in the second grade and has several friends at school.  She is doing well academically, can tie her shoes independently, and is an adept soccer player.  Medical history is significant for recurrent ear infections.  The patient is up to date on vaccinations and takes no daily medications.  Weight is at the 50th percentile and height is at the 2nd percentile for age.  Physical examination shows a stocky appearance with a short, wide neck and broad chest.  The palate is high arching.  Distal pulses are equal throughout.  There is no abdominal organomegaly.  The lower extremities are short relative to the trunk.  Compared to the general population, this patient is at the greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questionList.explanationText:
Comorbidity screening in Turner syndrome

Cardiovascular

  • Congenital heart defects*: 4-extremity BP, ECG, echocardiogram
  • Aortic dilatation/dissection**: TTE or cardiac MRI
  • Metabolic syndrome: BP, HbA1c, lipid panel, LFT

Renal

  • Horseshoe kidney: renal ultrasound

Musculoskeletal

  • Osteoporosis: 25-hydroxyvitamin D level, DXA scan

Vision & hearing

  • Strabismus, myopia: ophthalmology evaluation
  • Recurrent otitis media, hearing loss: audiology testing

Autoimmune

  • Celiac disease: tissue transglutaminase antibodies
  • Hypothyroidism: TSH, free T4

*Aortic coarctation, bicuspid aortic valve.

**High risk in pregnancy.

BP = blood pressure; HbA1c = glycosylated hemoglobin; LFT = liver function test;
TTE = transthoracic echocardiogram.

The patient's short stature; high-arched palate; short, wide (webbed) neck; and broad chest are characteristic features of Turner syndrome (TS) (45,X).  TS, the most common sex-chromosome abnormality, is caused by complete or partial loss of an X chromosome.

Cardiovascular abnormalities are the most life-threatening comorbidities associated with TS, with the most serious being aortic dissection or rupture.  Although dissection can occur in the absence of any other cardiac anomalies, risk is higher in patients with bicuspid aortic valve or coarctation of the aorta, left-sided heart defects commonly seen with TS.  Hypertension is also prevalent in patients with TS and contributes to the increased risk for aortic dissection.  Other cardiac conditions associated with TS include conduction abnormalities (eg, QT prolongation) and coronary artery disease.

All patients with TS require screening for cardiac disease with 4-extremity blood pressures, ECG, and imaging (eg, echocardiography, cardiac MRI).  If aortic dilatation is detected, beta blockers and aggressive blood pressure control are indicated; surgical repair may be considered based on aortic size and risk factors.

(Choices B)  Bronchiectasis (ie, thickened, dilated bronchioles) typically results from chronic/recurrent pulmonary infections, as seen in patients with cystic fibrosis or immunodeficiency syndromes.  Recurrent otitis media is common in TS due to anatomic ear malformations that cause eustachian tube abnormalities; however, recurrent pneumonia and bronchiectasis are not seen.

(Choice C)  Spontaneous pneumothorax is most common in tall, adolescent boys or in patients with underlying lung disease, risk factors not seen in this case.  Structural abnormalities (eg, Marfan, Ehlers-Danlos) also increase the risk for pneumothorax.  TS is not associated with pneumothorax.

(Choice D)  The most common renal manifestations of TS include horseshoe kidney and duplication of the collecting system; renal cell carcinoma is not an associated condition.

(Choice E)  Spinal stenosis (narrowing of the spinal canal) is a common complication of achondroplasia due to prominent lumbar lordosis in these patients.  Although this patient has short stature with a low leg-to-trunk ratio (a finding shared by achondroplasia and TS), her broad chest, wide neck, and high-arched palate make TS more likely.  Spinal stenosis is not typical of TS.

Educational objective:
Turner syndrome, often suspected based on short stature and webbed neck, is associated with an increased risk for cardiovascular abnormalities, including aortic dissection and rupture.  Cardiac screening (eg, echocardiography, 4-extremity blood pressures) is indicated to evaluate for bicuspid aortic valve, coarctation of the aorta, and aortic root dilation.
